_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1. Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies:
We at Bayer MaterialScience are committed to employee, public, and environmental safety. This is demonstrated by our
accidental release prevention practices that cover areas such as design, installation, operating procedures, maintenance,
and employee training associated with the storage and distribution processes at our facility. It is our policy to implement
appropriate controls to prevent possible releases of regulated substances. If such a release were to occur, trained
emergency response personnel are available to control and mitigate the effects of the release. This includes the local Fire
Department.
2. The Facility and the Regulated Substances Handled:
Our facility's primary activities encompass warehousing and wholesaling of chemicals. We have one substance present at
our facility that is regulated under the EPA Risk Management Regulation. This substance, toluene diisocyanate, is used
as a reactant in the manufacturing of flexible polyurethane foams and other elastomers. No manufacturing of any type or
processing of toluene diisocyanate or any other chemical takes place at this facility. The toluene diisocyanate is stored in
55 gallon drums and the maximum inventory at our facility is 300,000 lb.
3. The General Accidental Release Prevention Program and the Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps:
As a Program Level One facility, we are not required to have a written prevention program according to the EPA definition;
however, we have taken many steps to help ensure accidental release prevention. All materials are stored in containers
constructed according to Federal Department of Transportation (DOT) requirements. The closed containers are stored in
accordance with the National Fire Protection Agency (NFPA) codes. Containers are inspected for integrity when pulling
orders for shipment and during the loading process. In addition, the following elements of a release prevention program
are in practic

e at our facility.
-Employee Participation
-Process Safety Information
-Process Hazard Analysis
-Operating Procedures
-Training
-Contractor Safety
-Pre-startup Reviews
-Mechanical Integrity
-Safe Work Practices
-Management of Change
-Incident Investigation
-Compliance Audits
4. Five-year Accident History
Due to our stringent release prevention policies, there has been no accidental release during the last 5 years.
5. Emergency Response Plan
Our facility maintains a written emergency response plan to deal with accidental releases of hazardous materials. The
plan includes all aspects of emergency response including adequate first aid and medical treatment, evacuations,
notification of local emergency response agencies and the public, as well as post-incident decontamination of affected
areas.
To ensure proper functioning, our emergency response equipment is regularly inspected and serviced. In addition, the
plan is promptly updated to reflect any pertinent changes taking place within our facility that would require a modified
emergency response.
6. Planned Changes to Improve Safety
There are no new developments and no findings that have resulted from the practice of the various accidental release
prevention elements. No recommendations have been made.
